Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: STEM Education in Virtual Worlds Workshop Series

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance and importance of this project is the creation of two workshops that will focus on learning of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) subjects in Virtual Worlds and how other education technologies can be augmented with Virtual Worlds. At each workshop, STEM educators will share their research and learn from specialists in education and industry. Anticipated outcomes of the workshops include improved educational activities for college students in STEM fields, faculty with a better understanding of how students learn STEM subjects using Virtual Worlds, and stronger collaborations between educators and Virtual World designers in the computer/software industry.

The goals and scope of this project include the development of two workshops that will bring together faculty and industry representatives to share knowledge and create a strong scholarly Virtual World community that can integrate Virtual Worlds into the STEM curriculum. Participants will share their experiences with dissemination, assessment and institutionalization of Virtual Worlds in the classroom. Each four-day workshop will offer in-depth research presentations, hands-on experiences, engaging activities, and lively discussions. The PIs will invite approximately thirty attendees to each workshop. In addition, experts in curriculum design and assessment will help STEM educators understand how to develop activities with achievable, measurable learning objectives. Industry experts, such as programmers and representatives from companies developing virtual reality hardware and software, will share their technical knowledge and learn about the needs of educators who use their services and products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broader Impacts

Computer-based virtual worlds provide new interactive experiences that engage students’ interests and make science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines more appealing. Workshops and conferences such as those supported by this NSF grant help faculty develop high-quality virtual activities and integrate them into their classes. Long-term benefits of improved virtual worlds include increased participation by women in online STEM classes (70% of current online students are women), students with physical disabilities who would be otherwise unable to participate in laboratory activities, and students whose educational experience does not include access to hands-on activities such as lab experiments. Attendance by industry representatives strengthened partnerships between academic users and industry developers. The conference and workshop were open to faculty, staff, and students at the host universities and the public. Students who assisted the PIs with coordinating the workshops benefited from exposure to the workshop content and gained experience with a variety of soft skills required to conduct collaborative research.

Intellectual Merit

By bringing together education researchers and practitioners interested in virtual worlds and their uses in college-level STEM education, these events accomplished many goals:

1. Catalyzed the dissemination of knowledge within this small but growing community,

2. Fostered new collaborations among participants,

3. Increased the understanding of the role that virtual activities can play in post-secondary STEM education, and

4. Provided insight into effective use of virtual environments and digital learning aids.

These workshops were the first of their kind to focus on the specific challenges and opportunities for STEM education in virtual worlds. Advancing the effective development, implementation and assessment of learning in virtual worlds holds the possibility of transforming undergraduate education in the STEM disciplines by creating new interactive activities for students around the world. 

Summary 

PI Winkelmann organized and hosted the Virtual Worlds in Education research conference at Florida Tech in summer 2017. PI Ryoo organized and hosted a faculty workshop on the same topic at Penn State Altoona in summer 2017. Following these events, the PIs organized online meetings for attendees and other interested researchers. Attendance grew steadily then it was decided to start a Facebook group focused on virtual learning environments, which continues. A special issue of the Journal of Interactive learning Environments highlights the accomplishments of this project. This issue will be published in December 2019.

Beyond the conference, workshop, and special journal issue, the success of this conference and the sustained interest in virtual learning environments among faculty led the PIs to organize a 2018 Future of Innovative Learning Environments workshop (NSF award 1848612).
